question: Air embolism is best diagnosed by?
exp: Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE):- has the highest sensitivity for detecting the presence of air in the right ventricular outflow tract or major pulmonary veins. - It can detect as little as 0. 02 mL/kg of air administered by bolus injection. It also has the added advantage of identifying Paradoxical Air Embolism (PAE), and Doppler allows audible detection of venous air embolism (VAE). Overall highest sensitivity:- T. E. E > Doppler > E. T N2> E. T CO2

question: A 52-year-old businessman with nephrotic syndrome after a non-stop flight from New York to New Delhi presents with sudden onset of breathlessness, haemoptysis, and chest pain. He is brought into Casualty in shock. His chest X-ray is normal. The ECG shows sinus tachycardia.
exp: 1. In this patient no pulmonary edema, MI absent and aoic dissection also absent. 2. Nephrotic syndrome patient will be in hypercoagulable state, long flight- DVT- pulmonary embolism- acute Cor pulmonale 3. Most common causes of Cor pulmonale- pulmonary embolism 4. CXR is normal because it is only a small clot and clot usually not visible on X-ray

question: A patient presents with fracture of femur. On 3rd day of admission he develops breathlessness. Most probable diagnosis is?
exp: Fracture of femur- Cause immobilization | Stasis in calf veins | Thrombus formation- Retrograde spread- Pulmonary embolism

question: Which investigation is most diagnostic of pulmonary emboli?
exp: Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) is the initial imaging modality of choice for stable patients with a suspected pulmonary embolism. Pulmonary angiography shows emboli directly but it is an invasive procedure CT is noninvasive, cheaper and widely available. so, it's the most diagnostic investigation of choice. - D-Dimer is the screening investigationin PE pt's

question: After total knee implant surgery, a 65-year-old woman complains of calf pain and swelling in the leg from last 2 days. Later she complains of breathlessness and dies suddenly in the ward. What is the probable cause?
exp: PE and DVT occurring after total hip or knee replacement are prevented by giving subcutaneous fondaparinux. Pt with DVT has H/O cramp in the lower calf that persists for several days and becomes more uncomfoable as time progresses. Pt with PE often has the most common history of unexplained breathlessness. - ARDS is being ruled out as the presentation is acute with decrease in PCWP <18mm. Hg with B/L pulmonary infilteration on CXR - Stroke and MI has no H/O post op. breathlessness and such presentation.

question: In case of pulmonary embolism, right ventricle hypokinesia, and decreased output, which drug therapy is most helpful?
exp: Anticoagulation with Heparin has long been the standard treatment for normotensive patients with pulmonary embolism. By preventing clot propagation, heparin allows endogenous fibrinolysis to occur, with eventual resolution of thrombo-emboli. However in the absence of an absolute contraindication, patients with pulmonary embolism-induced hypotension or shock are usually treated with thrombolytic agents. The three thrombolytic agents used in treatment of pulmonary embolism are streptokinase, urokinase and recombinant tissue-type plasminogen activator(-PA).

question: Comment on the diagnosis of the patient.
exp: Given X ray shows prominent descending right pulmonary aery- giving "Jug handle" appearance Aoic Dissection - seen on CT COA - 3 sign TOF - Boot shaped heart

question: Which of the following conditions is most likely to occur in a patient with the following hemodynamic data? Pressures: RA = 12 mm Hg, RV = 50/12 mm Hg, PA=50/15 mm Hg, PA wedge pressure = 8 mm Hg, Aoa=80/60, Cardiac Index = 1. 4, SVR= 1800, PVR=500.
exp: Normal pressure Value given ( in mm. Hg) Interpretation RA = 2-6 mm. Hg 12 Elevated RV = 25/5 mm. Hg 50/12 Elevated Pulmonary aery = 25/10mm. Hg 50/15 Elevated PCWP = 8 -12 mm. Hg 8 Normal Aoa = < 120/80 80/60 Hypotension The presence of Normal PCWP rules out the primary involvement of left side heart. so, Acute MI with LVF is ruled out. Hypovolemic shock following Gastroenteritis will lead to under-filling of the right side of heart but this patient has elevated pressure values on the right side of the heart. Early septic shock will lead to increased cardiac output but this patient has hypotension. (ruled out) Increased RA, PV pressure with PAH indicates RV malfunction. Less flow to lungs will lead to systemic hypotension. Hence, the patient has presentation of Acute Cor-Pulmonale.
opb: Acute MI with LVF and cardiogenic shock

question: What is the most common ECG finding for pulmonary embolism?
exp: M/C ECG abnormality in pulmonary embolism- Sinus tachycardia M/C symptom is unexplained breathlessness. Screening test - D-dimer test. Most specific finding is S1. Q3. T3. The classic findings of right heart strain and acute cor pulmonale are tall, peaked P waves in lead II (P pulmonale); right axis detion; right bundle-branch block and S1. Q3. T3 pattern.

question: Lovibond angle is:
exp: Lovibond angle or Hyponychial angle - Angle between nail bed and proximal nail fold - Normally around 1600. - It is >1800 in digital clubbing. It is described as a 'profile sign'
opa: Angle between the iris and cornea
opb: Angle between the long axis of the forearm and the long axis of upper arm
opc: Angle between nail bed and proximal nail fold
opd: Angle between manubrium sternum and body of sternum
